lines.content: Node is a simple command-line chatbot designed to help users manage tasks efficiently. Users can add, delete, mark, unmark, find, and list tasks. The chatbot supports ToDo, Deadline, and Event tasks, and it stores tasks persistently in a file.
Description: Node supports three types of tasks: ToDo, Deadline, and Event.
Tasks are stored in a list.
Description: Adds a basic task without any date/time attached to it. First bracket will contain the letter "t"
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 1 task in the list.
Description: Adds a task that need to be done before a specific date/time. First bracket will contain the letter "d"
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 1 tasks in the list.
Description: Adds a task that start at a specific date/time and ends at a specific date/time. First bracket will contain the letter "E"
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 1 tasks in the list.
Description: Displays all current tasks with their status (done or not done).
Here are the tasks in your list:
Description: Marks a task as completed by adding "X" in second bracket.
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
Description: Marks a task as uncompleted by removing "X" in second bracket.
OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:
Description: Removes a task from the list permanently.
Now you have 2 tasks in the list.
Description: Find a task by searching for a keyword in the task description.
Here are the matching tasks in your list:
Description: Closes the chatbot and exits the program.
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
* Represents a deadline task that has a specific time to be completed by.
* Constructs a Deadline task with the specified description and time.
* @param description The description of the task.
* @param by The deadline time as a string in the format "d/M/yyyy HHmm".
* Parses a string representing the date and time into a LocalDateTime object.
* @param dateTime The date and time string to parse.
* @return The corresponding LocalDateTime object, or null if parsing fails.
System.out.println("Invalid date format! Use d/M/yyyy HHmm (e.g., 2/12/2019 1800).");
* Returns a string representation of the Deadline task in the format:
* The date will be formatted as "MMM dd yyyy, h:mm a" (e.g., Dec 02 2019, 6:00 PM).
* @return A string representation of the deadline task.
DateTimeFormatter outputFormat = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy, h:mm a");
* Returns a string representation of the Deadline task for file storage in the format:
* The date and time are formatted as "d/M/yyyy HHmm".
* @return A string representation of the deadline task for file storage.
* Represents an event task in the task management system.
* Extends the {@link Task} class and adds the ability to store event start and end times.
* The start time of the event.
* The end time of the event.
* Constructs an Event with the given description, start time, and end time.
* @param description A brief description of the event.
* @param from The start time of the event.
* @param to The end time of the event.
public Event(String description, String from, String to) {
* Converts the Event object to a string that can be saved to a file.
* @return A string representation of the Event in a format suitable for saving to a file.
* Returns a string representation of the Event object, which includes its status, description,
* and the event's start and end times.
* @return A string representation of the Event object.
* Represents a Node in the system that manages tasks and interacts with the user.
* It handles the loading and saving of tasks, as well as processing user commands.
* Constructs a Node with a specified file path to load and save task data.
* Initializes the UI, Storage, Parser, and TaskList components.
* @param filePath the path to the file where task data is stored
* Runs the main loop of the Node system. It shows a welcome message, reads and processes user input,
* and continues until the user exits. Commands are processed and executed based on the input.
* The entry point of the Node application. Creates a new Node instance with a given file path
* @param args the command-line arguments (not used in this implementation)
* Handles parsing and execution of user commands.
* Processes a user command and executes the corresponding action.
* @param command The full command input by the user.
* @param tasks The list of tasks currently being managed.
* @param ui The user interface to display messages.
* @param storage The storage system to save and load tasks.
* @return true if the program should continue running, false if it should exit.
* @throws NodeException If there is an error in processing the command.
public boolean processCommand(String command, TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws NodeException {
if (deadlineParts.length < 2) throw new NodeException("Invalid deadline format.");
if (eventParts.length < 3) throw new NodeException("Invalid event format.");
throw new NodeException("Please provide a keyword to search for.");
throw new NodeException("OOPS!!! I'm sorry, but I don't know what that means :-(");

* Initializes the Storage with a specified file path.
* Creates the necessary folder structure if it doesn't exist.
* @param filePath The file path where tasks are stored.
* Creates the parent folder if it doesn't exist.
* Loads the list of tasks from the file.
* If the file doesn't exist, returns an empty list.

* @throws NodeException If an error occurs while loading the tasks.

throw new NodeException("Error loading tasks from file.");

throw new NodeException("Error saving tasks to file.");
* Abstract class representing a task in a task management system.
* This class contains common fields and methods for all types of tasks, such as a description and completion status.
* The completion status of the task (true if done, false otherwise).
* Constructs a new Task with the given description and marks it as not done.
* @param description A brief description of the task.
* Gets the description of the task.
* Marks the task as not done.
* Returns the status icon for the task. This is "[X]" if the task is done, and "[ ]" if it is not done.
* @return The status icon representing the task's completion status.
return (isDone ? "[X]" : "[ ]"); // Mark done tasks with an "X"
* Converts the task to a string that can be saved to a file.
* The exact format depends on the subclass.
* @return A string representation of the task in a format suitable for saving to a file.
* Returns a string representation of the task that includes its status and description.
* For example, "[X] Task description" or "[ ] Task description".
* @return A string representation of the task.
* Creates a Task object from a saved string representation.
* The string should be in the format: "<taskType> | <isDone> | <description> | <additionalFields>".
* @param line The string representation of the task.
* @return The Task object created from the string.
* @throws NodeException If the string is corrupted or the task type is unknown.
public static Task fromString(String line) throws NodeException {

* Handles displaying messages and reading user input.
* Initializes the user interface by setting up the scanner for input.
* Displays a welcome message with the application logo and a prompt.
System.out.println("What can I do for you?");

* @return The input command entered by the user.

System.out.println("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
